ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
Breakout rooms, and discussion (around 11 people I think). Mostly lecture, but with lots of student questions and sentence translation, etc.
TA tutorial over zoom.
Virtual seminar-style class.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My language skills and general familiarity increased greatly. My reading and speaking improved, and the tutorials helped me become comfortable with 1-on-1 Mandarin conversation, where I hadn't been before. My comprehension is much better, but so is the amount vocabulary I know and am comfortable using.

During second year Chinese we moved past word choice, pronunciations, and simple sentences. I learned to read long paragraphs, listen to more complicated recordings, and write and speak and a higher level.
I significantly increased my Chinese proficiency, especially in listening and speaking
Chinese reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills.
I gained a wider vocabulary and grammar skill-set this semester and made large improvements in my listening and speaking fluency.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Consistent speaking challenges (oral presentations, tutorials, daily class participation), encouraging instructor, non-intimidating class environment, good online resources
Weaknesses: Not much hand-writing practice, sometimes not enough time to get corrections (tones/pronunciation/grammar) because of short class period, extremely difficult reading tests
Ms. Xu is a fantastic teacher. She is the best Chinese teacher I have ever had.

Strengths:
- Dedicated and engaging professor
- Good textbook
- A lot of homework - but no too much. Just enough for me to engage with the material without feeling overwhelmed. 

Weaknesses:
- Class time can be used more effectively in a virtual format
- Teacher often conducted the class past the scheduled end time of the course
I felt like it improved my learning greatly, but the workload was so high that it caused me a great deal of stress.
The course is very work intensive but extremely well taught.

Having the predominant language in class be China was very helpful in boosting my fluency this semester. The homework workloadthe essays in particularfelt more effective and less-redundant than in the first two levels. One aspect of Chinese-learning that I missed from last year was the character-writing. Although I feel like I learned more characters in general, my ability to hand-write them has decreased because of online learning.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Improved: During class, the use of breakout rooms could be improved if we were provided with handouts and such from before class that can be used during the breakout room so that my classmates and I have a better idea of how to use our time together. Additionally, during class, the parts where we just repeated what the teacher was saying felt of little value to me.
I think this class worked surprising well considering the pandemic. I liked the breakout rooms, and the fact that attendance was mandatory helped me stay engaged and stuff.
Zoom classes were well done.

The class translated well to online learning, in some cases becoming even more focused and efficient for student-teacher dialectic training. However, the loss of writing characters has decreased my ability to hand-write in Chinese.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student, absolutely, because I think my growth in this semester alone matches the growth I experienced in three years of high school Chinese. I was excited to be in class every day.
I will definitely be recommending Ms. Xu's courses.
Yes! If you want to learn Mandarin that is.
I would recommend this course it they would like to increase their Chinese proficiency, but be ready for the huge workload.
Yes, if you have the time to commit and the interest.

If you are really invested/interested in taking Chinese, do it! Yale's Chinese classes are very well organized and, as long as you keep up with the homework, you are set up to succeed. The instructors are all very approachable and they make classtime engaging and fun. If you are looking to just learn any language, though, beware that the workload for Chinesealthough not unmanageableis constant and modestly large.
